posts.name: Ezra
posts.cooked: I’m looking into CAD solutions for electronics and the first thing that came to mind was SOLIDWORKS Electrical Professional, which is said to come with the SOLIDWORKS package for FRC . I couldn’t find Electrical Professional and assumed it meant 3D/2D, which didn’t work with the code and when I tried to activate it it said my license didn’t cover it. I’m wondering if anyone has gotten SOLIDWORKS Electrical working or if there are any recommendations on other softwares that we should use for CADing the electronics of the robot.

posts.name: Jonathan shani
posts.cooked:
I use Solidworks electrical to model our company’s wire harnesses and make drawings to send out to manufacturers.

I must say that it’s a big hassle and time sink to get right. I think it would take me at least a day’s work ( 9 hours) to cad the wiring of an entire FRC robot and that’s when I have my entire library of parts prepared beforehand and the workflow figured out. May I ask what is your intention for using electrical?

posts.name: Liam
posts.cooked: Do you want a 2D wire map layout or do you want to model your wires onto your 3D robot?

posts.name: Ezra
posts.cooked:
Jonathanshani:

May I ask what is your intention for using electrical?

I’m looking for a software where I can plan out in depth the wiring plan of the robot while it’s still just the CAD

trixydevs:

Do you want a 2D wire map layout or do you want to model your wires onto your 3D robot?

Something 3D would be best, but if there are compelling reasons on why not to I’m open to suggestions

posts.name: Liam
posts.cooked:
We use FRITZING to map out our wiring in 2D. It tends to be a lot clearer for those doing the work.

We also map out our physical components (not wires) in CAD so that we know how to route them.

We tend to place electronics in FRITZING in a similar to CAD and intuitive layout.

Here are those resources(please note they are far from complete and are mainly for 2491 as of now):

GitHub - 2491-NoMythic/FRITZING-Wiring-Diagram-Repositories: This is where all of the repositories for our... This is where all of the repositories for our FRITZING wiring diagrams will be stored. Each robot will get its own folder.

This is where all of the repositories for our FRITZING wiring diagrams will be stored. Each robot will get its own folder.

Achieving Wiring Credentials	3 From 0 To Competition Ready Robot	4 Basic Skills, and Best Practices	5 Crimping	6 Labeling	6 Using Regular Label Maker	6 Using The Heat Shrink Label Maker	7 Wire Management	7 Routing & Bundling	7 Zip Ties	10...

posts.name: Ezra
posts.cooked: Do you know if/what is included in the FRC package? Even if it’s not very viable, I’m sure it’s something worth looking into

posts.name: Jonathan shani
posts.cooked: I actually never checked that out in an FRC context so no… I would actually probably recommend just sketching out the wires using 3d sketch and using a sweep.  (Since constraining the wiring to be realistic in electrical is pretty similar) It might be faster for you guys.

posts.name: Ezra
posts.cooked: This stuff looks great, but after looking at it I’m pretty sure I’m looking for something 3D. The 2D stuff looks very useful for seeing what components connect and how, but I’m looking for a way to see more about how each component connects and where everything will go on the actual robot. All the electronics sheets were very informative though and I just might reference some sections from them, so thanks

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
In all the decades I have worked designing electrical and electronic equipment at a wide variety of companies, we have never drawn the wiring in the 3D model.

We make a schematic drawing showing how all the wires connect with the various components. The focus is on showing the functionality of the product.

We also make a spreadsheet showing the starting and ending  points of each wire, the wire gauge, the wire color, and any labels applied to each wire. The approximate length and any connector contacts are also indicated. These spreadsheets are given to the contractors specializing in making the wire looms for us.

There are wiring channels indicated in the 3D mechanical CAD model.

I only recall two situations where wiring was drawn in the 3D mechanical CAD model. One was to work othe routing for a few large 4/0 cables. The other was to provide a graphic image of the product for the Marketing department. It might not have been accurate.

We used a wiring spreadsheet to design the wiring before building the robot this past season and found it worked well for us.

To work out the physical routing of the wires, we took multipe screenshots of the 3D mechanical CAD from a variety of different view points. We then drew in wiring paths with different colors for bundles of power wires, control/ CAN wires, and ethernet/USB cables. It was fast and efficient. We were able to try different routes to optimize.
